awd_titl_txt: CPS: Frontiers: Collaborative Research: ROSELINE: Enabling Robust, Secure and Efficient Knowledge of Time Across the System Stack
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurate and reliable knowledge of time is fundamental to cyber-physical systems for sensing, control, performance, and energy efficient integration of computing and communications. This statement underlies the proposal. Emerging CPS applications depend on precise knowledge of time to infer location and control communication. There is a diversity of semantics used to describe time, and quality of time varies as we move up and down the system stack. System designs tend to overcompensate for these uncertainties and the result is systems that may be over designed, inefficient, and fragile.

The intellectual merit derives from the new and fundamental concept of time and the holistic measure of quality of time (QoT) that captures metrics including resolution, accuracy, and stability. The proposal builds a system stack ("ROSELINE") that enables new ways for clock hardware, operating system, network services, and applications to learn, maintain and exchange information about time, influence component behavior, and robustly adapt to dynamic QoT requirements, as well as to benign and adversarial changes in operating conditions. Application areas that will benefit from Quality of Time will include: smart grad, networked and coordinated control of aerospace systems, underwater sensing, and industrial automation.

The broader impact of the proposal is due to the foundational nature of the work which builds a robust and tunable quality of time that can be applied across a broad spectrum of applications that pervade modern life. The proposal will also provide valuable opportunities to integrate research and education in graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 classrooms. There will be extensive outreach through publications, open sourcing of software, and participation in activities such as the Los Angeles Computing Circle for pre-college students.

por.por_cntn:
Activities in the Roseline project, a multi-institutional collaboration, focused on developing technologies, algorithms, and foundational  concepts necessary for efficient cyber-physical systems that are robust to uncertainty in timing information available to them.  The UCLA researchers made the following contributions towards the project?s objectives:

1.  New operating system abstractions and  mechanisms for time

For operating systems to support time-centric cyber-physical applications robustly and efficiently, it is critical that they provide applications with time related information in a manner that is secure while allowing visibility into and control over its uncertainty.  Project researchers developed a variety of new OS abstractions and mechanisms towards this purpose. These included:

(a) Timelines, which allow applications to create bespoke clocks with specified levels of quality and enable OS to manage hardware resources efficiently. The researchers released an open-source modular implementation of Timelines for the popular Linux  operating system running on Arm and Intel x86 processors.

(b) Timeseal, which allows  applications to securely receive information about the current time even when the OS or the communication network are untrusted and vulnerable to attacks that tamper with the timing information. The researchers developed methods that allow applications running inside the SGX trusted execution enclaves on Intel?s x86 processors to receive timing information that is secure, accurate, and high-resolution.

2. Ultra-low-power clocks for efficient high-quality time

Providing time information at acceptable quality is particularly challenging in resource-constrained embedded wireless scenarios common in  edge computing and Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems. These systems are often battery-operated and therefore put to sleep when their functions are not needed, thus making the power consumed by the clock generator hardware as well as the delay in waking up this hardware a bottleneck. The researchers developed  new ultra-power-efficient clocks and implemented them as CMOS integrated circuits:

(a) Quick startup crystal-oscillators (XO) that use precisely-timed pre-energization of crystal to enable aggressive duty cycling of IoT hardware including the XO circuitry, yielding high quality XOs with parts-per-million stability with startup delays of only 100 cycles (which is fastest to-date) and relatively insensitive to variability.

(b) Ultra-low-power (sub-nW) 32-kHz XO for real time clock (RTC)  that uses a novel time-varying sustaining amplifier to reduce energy of always-ON RTC to 0.55nW  which is the lowest reported power consumption (3x lower than prior art). This work received a US Patent.

3. Machine learning methods for robust inferences under poor timing

Many cyber-physical applications depend on modern machine learning methods that utilize deep neural networks learnt from data to process sensor data for purposes of extracting insights from them and deciding on control actions. As the deep neural networks have a large number of parameters with no human understanding of their role, it is difficult to make the processing by neural networks  robust to poor quality of timing information, such as erroneous time stamps and incorrect time alignment across different sensors, and delays in distributed systems. By contrast, in classical first-principles algorithmic approaches that are used for simpler sensors, the algorithm parameters have explicit representations of time and thus allow imperfections in time to be reasoned about and compensated. The researchers developed a suite of computational methods by which one  can mitigate poor quality of time, including:

(a) Time-shift data augmentation, a novel approach that makes deep neural network models robust to poor time alignment in multisensor and multimodal fusion settings by deliberately introducing artificially generated temporal shifts in sensor data at the time of model training. This approach of making deep neural models intrinsically robust to poor quality of time  is computationally more efficient than repairing the sensor data at run time, leading to lower latency and higher efficiency.

(b) Time-in-state reinforcement learning (TSRL), that makes deep reinforcement learning used in data-driven cyber-physical systems for control robust to variations in sensor-to-actuation delays which are difficult to capture at the time of model training. TSRL extends the observed state of the system by explicitly including time-delays, i.e., incorporating the variation introduced by the sensor sampling interval and execution latency at training time. Results show that it enables much higher performance than traditional approaches that are unaware of time characteristics.

4. Los Angeles Computing Circle

The UCLA  team organized, supervised, and contributed content to the Los Angeles Computing Circle, (http://lacc.ee.ucla.edu)  outreach program focused on engaging and mentoring younger students for careers in computing and engineering. Organized each summer as a sequence of self-contained modules,  LACC provides Grade 9-12 students an opportunity to learn advanced concepts in computing via lectures and hands-on design and programming laboratories. It complements and goes beyond the abstract exposure to computing that the traditional high school computer science curriculum offers by way of AP CS and related courses. During the pandemic the UCLA team created a virtual version of the program, and extended it to incoming computer engineering undergraduate students as well.
